messages.msgSnippet: I would think it more likely that the habaki is an expression of the owner/user s political allegiance, rather than indicating a solid Tokugawa connection.
messages.messageBody:
I would think it more likely that the habaki is an expression of the owner/user's political allegiance, rather than indicating a "solid" Tokugawa connection. Of course, by this time I imagine the aoi mon was being used as a "decorator" item by all and sundry with no fear of losing one's head!! As Peter observed, if the habaki is a high quality item it points more to my first suggestion and if poorer quality then to the second. Here in Australia there is a Koto wakizashi by (I think) IESUKE (nijimei) that has a solid gold niju habaki with a sukashi Oda mon. The quality is just excellent, but is it a "connection/allegiance" piece or a "decorator"?? Without a large number of documented similar pieces we will never know.

Barry Thomas

----- Original Message -----
From: Ron Hartmann
To: token_kenkyu_kai@... ; nihontostudy ; nihonto@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, April 02, 2007 6:41 AM
Subject: [nihonto] Yamon Naokatsu


Hi all -

Does anyone know of any connection that Yamon Naokatsu (2nd generation) had with the Tokugawa? Reason I ask, I have a short katana by Shoji Yamon Naokatsu (dated Meiji 4 - 1871) which has a silver habaki with the Tokugawa aoi crest on it in sukashi (pierced). I believe this habaki was original to the sword (not a collector's replacement) but so far I've yet to find some connection between the smith and the Tokugawa.

Thanks,

Ron
STL
